intro: Beadlea storeri, commonly known as the Storer's beadlea, is a rare flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, greenish-yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to survive in drought conditions. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Beadlea storeri is considered a species of conservation concern.
